path_1.title: Kung Fu Panda (2008)
path_1.feeling: Funny and endearing, but the slick modern animation doesn’t hit me as deeply as the old-school wonders I cherish.

path_1.title: Finding Nemo (2003)
path_1.feeling: Warm, visually lush adventure with enough heart and craft to keep me hooked.

path_1.title: Bambi (1942)
path_1.feeling: Elegant and tender, its seasonal rhythms and gentle melancholy work on me.

path_1.title: Christmas Carol, A (1938)
path_1.feeling: A cozy redemption tale I enjoy in doses, even if it feels a bit softened.

path_1.title: Bothersome Man, The (Brysomme mannen, Den) (2006)
path_1.feeling: A cool, unsettling allegory with a trancelike mood I gravitate toward.

path_1.title: Eastern Promises (2007)
path_1.feeling: Taut, brutal crime drama with a cold elegance I appreciate.

path_1.title: Handful of Dust, A (1988)
path_1.feeling: Well-mannered ache and social rot, affecting but a touch too reserved for me.

path_1.title: Paperhouse (1988)
path_1.feeling: Dreamlike and eerie, a moody fusion of childhood fantasy and dread that fits my tastes.

path_1.title: Big Combo, The (1955)
path_1.feeling: Hard-edged, shadow-drenched noir that hits my sweet spot perfectly.

path_1.title: Ravenous (1999)
path_1.feeling: Macabre, offbeat genre mash-up that keeps a sly grin with a nasty bite.

path_1.title: Gold Diggers of 1933 (1933)
path_1.feeling: Snappy Depression-era showmanship with bite—I’m happily swept along.

path_1.title: Old Boy (2003)
path_1.feeling: Relentless and twisted, its operatic drive outweighs the cruelty for me.

path_1.title: Farewell to Arms, A (1932)
path_1.feeling: A classic romance that leaves me cool despite the wartime sweep.

path_1.title: Time After Time (1979)
path_1.feeling: High-concept chase with playful charm—fun more than profound.

path_1.title: Gunfight at the O.K. Corral (1957)
path_1.feeling: Solid, upright western that lacks the moral shadows I crave.

path_1.title: Snapper, The (1993)
path_1.feeling: Warm and wry, a small-town family tangle that charms without fully knocking me out.

path_1.title: Last Days, The (1998)
path_1.feeling: Stately and cerebral, worthwhile but a bit dry for me.

path_1.title: Jackie Brown (1997)
path_1.feeling: Low-key crime tapestry with lived-in grooves I enjoy.

path_1.title: Hound of the Baskervilles, The (1939)
path_1.feeling: Curse and investigation wrapped in classic, cozy dread—my kind of mystery.

path_1.title: One Day in September (1999)
path_1.feeling: A sober, riveting account that balances clarity with real moral weight.

path_1.title: Lookout, The (2007)
path_1.feeling: Tight, melancholy heist spiral with character focus I like.

path_1.title: Conformist, The (Conformista, Il) (1970)
path_1.feeling: Sumptuous and controlled—images carry as much power as the story.

path_1.title: Four Weddings and a Funeral (1994)
path_1.feeling: Amiable and breezy, sweet more than memorable for me.

path_1.title: All About My Mother (Todo sobre mi madre) (1999)
path_1.feeling: Compassionate, vibrant melodrama that pulls me in.

path_1.title: Hoodlum (1997)
path_1.feeling: Stylish period crime that satisfies even if it seldom surprises.

path_1.title: Ms. 45 (a.k.a. Angel of Vengeance) (1981)
path_1.feeling: Grimy, blunt urban revenge that scratches my exploitation-noir itch.

path_1.title: 35 Up (1991)
path_1.feeling: Deeply absorbing life mosaic—the cumulative time-lapse insight moves me.

path_2.title: Kung Fu Panda (2008)
path_2.feeling: Charming and fleet, but its broad uplift doesn’t quite hit my deeper sweet spots.

path_2.title: Finding Nemo (2003)
path_2.feeling: Tender, beautifully crafted adventure that earns its sentiment for me.

path_2.title: Bambi (1942)
path_2.feeling: Lyrical nature and quiet sorrow I appreciate, even if a touch of sweetness softens the sting.

path_2.title: Christmas Carol, A (1938)
path_2.feeling: Classic moral fable warmly done, if a bit tidy for my taste.

path_2.title: Bothersome Man, The (Brysomme mannen, Den) (2006)
path_2.feeling: A cool, eerie allegory whose sterile unease sits nicely with me.

path_2.title: Eastern Promises (2007)
path_2.feeling: Lean, bruising crime with moral shadows I like dwelling in.

path_2.title: Handful of Dust, A (1988)
path_2.feeling: Acid manners and marital rot engage me more intellectually than emotionally.

path_2.title: Paperhouse (1988)
path_2.feeling: Dreamlike dread and tender melancholy—right in my wheelhouse.

path_2.title: Big Combo, The (1955)
path_2.feeling: Hard-edged noir fatalism and chiaroscuro I absolutely savor.

path_2.title: Ravenous (1999)
path_2.feeling: Savage, sly genre mash that’s bloody, funny, and pleasingly perverse.

path_2.title: Gold Diggers of 1933 (1933)
path_2.feeling: Snappy pre-Code sparkle with socially tinged showmanship I enjoy.

path_2.title: Old Boy (2003)
path_2.feeling: Vengeful labyrinth of secrets—gripping, stylish, and deliciously cruel.

path_2.title: Farewell to Arms, A (1932)
path_2.feeling: Polished and earnest, but the romance leaves me a little cool.

path_2.title: Time After Time (1979)
path_2.feeling: Clever, breezy conceit with enough menace to keep me smiling.

path_2.title: Gunfight at the O.K. Corral (1957)
path_2.feeling: Solid, square-jawed western I respect more than I love.

path_2.title: Snapper, The (1993)
path_2.feeling: Warm, wry slice of life that charms without knocking me out.

path_2.title: Last Days, The (1998)
path_2.feeling: Stately and thoughtful, though it plays a bit didactic for me.

path_2.title: Jackie Brown (1997)
path_2.feeling: Wry, patient crime hangout with heart—my kind of slow-burn.

path_2.title: Hound of the Baskervilles, The (1939)
path_2.feeling: Foggy moor mood and mystery that tickles my classic-horror itch.

path_2.title: One Day in September (1999)
path_2.feeling: Riveting, sobering reportage that grips with clarity and urgency.

path_2.title: Lookout, The (2007)
path_2.feeling: Low-key neo-noir with human stakes and clean mechanics I admire.

path_2.title: Conformist, The (Conformista, Il) (1970)
path_2.feeling: Hypnotic design and moral rot—sumptuous and chilling.

path_2.title: Four Weddings and a Funeral (1994)
path_2.feeling: Effervescent and amiable, if lighter than the romances that haunt me.

path_2.title: All About My Mother (Todo sobre mi madre) (1999)
path_2.feeling: Vibrant, compassionate melodrama that moves with wit and grace.

path_2.title: Hoodlum (1997)
path_2.feeling: Period crime sheen that entertains but doesn’t cut deep for me.

path_2.title: Ms. 45 (a.k.a. Angel of Vengeance) (1981)
path_2.feeling: Grimy urban fury—blunt, pulpy, and queasily compelling.

path_2.title: 35 Up (1991)
path_2.feeling: Time’s quiet revelations land with cumulative power I love.

path_2.title: Kung Fu Panda (2008)
path_2.feeling: Breezy, well-crafted crowd-pleaser I enjoyed without needing it to linger.

path_2.title: Finding Nemo (2003)
path_2.feeling: Warm, funny, and handsomely made—sweet without tipping into syrup.

path_2.title: Bambi (1942)
path_2.feeling: A lyrical, lightly haunting nature fable I admire.

path_2.feeling: Classic moral ghost yarn that lands clean if a bit tidy.

path_2.title: Eastern Promises (2007)
path_2.feeling: Brutal, tight underworld currents—my crime sweet spot.

path_2.title: Handful of Dust, A (1988)
path_2.feeling: Cool, brittle manners and betrayal I respect more than I feel.

path_2.title: Paperhouse (1988)
path_2.feeling: Melancholy dream-logic and tender dread—right up my alley.

path_2.title: Big Combo, The (1955)
path_2.feeling: Sleek, vicious noir fatalism I savor.

path_2.title: Ravenous (1999)
path_2.feeling: Frontier dread and mordant humor make a lean, feral bite.

path_5.feeling: Breezy, big-hearted family shenanigans with enough bite to keep me invested.

path_5.title: Last Days, The (1998)
path_5.feeling: Philosophical history framed like a parable—engaging ideas, modest dramatic charge.

path_5.title: Jackie Brown (1997)
path_5.feeling: A sly, patient caper with lived-in characters—my kind of unflashy crime hangout.

path_5.title: Hound of the Baskervilles, The (1939)
path_5.feeling: Foggy moors and cursed bloodlines give this mystery the gothic snap I savor.

path_5.title: One Day in September (1999)
path_5.feeling: Riveting, rigorously assembled history that tightens the throat and the brain.

path_5.title: Lookout, The (2007)
path_5.feeling: A lean, empathetic noir that turns a small-town heist into a tense character study.

path_5.title: Conformist, The (Conformista, Il) (1970)
path_5.feeling: A cool, unsettling study of moral rot that hooked me with mood and fatalism.

path_5.title: Four Weddings and a Funeral (1994)
path_5.feeling: Light, amiable romcom pleasures—pleasant enough, if not my preferred flavor.

path_5.title: All About My Mother (Todo sobre mi madre) (1999)
path_5.feeling: A tender, jagged tapestry of grief and chosen family that hits my humanist buttons.

path_5.title: Hoodlum (1997)
path_5.feeling: Glossy period rackets I enjoy, even if the beats feel familiar.

path_5.title: Ms. 45 (a.k.a. Angel of Vengeance) (1981)
path_5.feeling: Grimy, night-walk vengeance with a jagged pulse—nasty but compelling.

path_5.title: 35 Up (1991)
path_5.feeling: Time-capsule documentary intimacy that floors me—quietly profound and addictive.

path_5.title: Kung Fu Panda (2008)
path_5.feeling: Energetic and warm, but the broad slapstick keeps it in the “pleasant” lane for me.

path_5.title: Finding Nemo (2003)
path_5.feeling: Tender, visually rich adventure that balances heart and humor without talking down.

path_5.title: Bambi (1942)
path_5.feeling: Gorgeously lyrical nature study whose sentiment mostly works on me.

path_5.title: Christmas Carol, A (1938)
path_5.feeling: Classic redemption tale I appreciate more for its seasonal mood than its softness.

path_5.title: Bothersome Man, The (Brysomme mannen, Den) (2006)
path_5.feeling: An uncanny, deadpan dystopia with the existential chill I gravitate toward.

path_5.title: Eastern Promises (2007)
path_5.feeling: Brutal, morally knotted underworld tale delivered with steely tension—very much my thing.

path_5.title: Handful of Dust, A (1988)
path_5.feeling: Acid English manners and marital rot interest me, if a touch genteel.

path_5.title: Paperhouse (1988)
path_5.feeling: Moody dream-logic coming-of-age that scratches my dark-fantasy itch.

path_5.title: Big Combo, The (1955)
path_5.feeling: Hardboiled, stylish noir fatalism—pure catnip.

path_5.title: Ravenous (1999)
path_5.feeling: Cannibal-western oddity with grim humor and atmosphere I can sink into.

path_5.title: Gold Diggers of 1933 (1933)
path_5.feeling: Snappy Depression musical with bite and backstage wit that I enjoy.

path_5.title: Old Boy (2003)
path_5.feeling: Operatic revenge and moral rot that hits hard and lingers.

path_5.title: Farewell to Arms, A (1932)
path_5.feeling: Classic weepie war romance I respect more than I feel.

path_5.title: Time After Time (1979)
path_5.feeling: Clever genre mashup—fun premise, lighter tone keeps me engaged if not haunted.

path_5.title: Gunfight at the O.K. Corral (1957)
path_5.feeling: Solid studio western mythmaking, satisfying if conventional.

path_5.title: Snapper, The (1993)
path_5.feeling: Warm, wry family dramedy with a grounded charm I can get behind.

path_5.title: Last Days, The (1998)
path_5.feeling: Philosophical and historical interest, but it reads a bit stagey for my taste.

path_5.title: Jackie Brown (1997)
path_5.feeling: Laid-back, character-rich crime with melancholy grace—right up my alley.

path_5.title: Hound of the Baskervilles, The (1939)
path_5.feeling: Foggy Gothic mystery comfort—lean, pulpy, satisfying.

path_5.title: One Day in September (1999)
path_5.feeling: Tense, incisive history doc that hits my docu-history sweet spot.

path_5.title: Lookout, The (2007)
path_5.feeling: Low-key noir with human stakes—tight, unflashy, effective.

path_5.title: Conformist, The (Conformista, Il) (1970)
path_5.feeling: Lush, morally queasy formalism—visual-and-thematic catnip.

path_5.title: Four Weddings and a Funeral (1994)
path_5.feeling: Witty and likable, though the romcom gloss keeps me at a mild remove.

path_5.title: All About My Mother (Todo sobre mi madre) (1999)
path_5.feeling: Compassionate, vibrant melodrama that lands with warmth and bite.

path_5.title: Hoodlum (1997)
path_5.feeling: Handsome period crime that plays, if a bit broad and conventional.

path_5.title: Ms. 45 (a.k.a. Angel of Vengeance) (1981)
path_5.feeling: Gritty, lean urban vengeance with exploitation bite—very much my lane.

path_5.title: 35 Up (1991)
path_5.feeling: Long-view human tapestry—quietly profound, exactly my documentary jam.

path_5.title: Kung Fu Panda (2008)
path_5.feeling: Energetic, lovingly choreographed animal-fu with heart, if the quips skew a bit too broad for my taste.

path_5.title: Finding Nemo (2003)
path_5.feeling: Gorgeous ocean odyssey with enough warmth and wonder to win me over, even if the sentiment runs sweet.

path_5.title: Bambi (1942)
path_5.feeling: Lyrical, seasonal melancholy and nature’s hush gave me that classic, quietly devastating glow.

path_5.title: Christmas Carol, A (1938)
path_5.feeling: Cozy, earnest ghost-morality tale that warms more than it thrills me.

path_5.title: Bothersome Man, The (Brysomme mannen, Den) (2006)
path_5.feeling: A deadpan, eerie parable whose sterile nightmare and fissures of beauty hit my woozy-fantasy sweet spot.

path_5.title: Eastern Promises (2007)
path_5.feeling: Sinewy, morally rank mob thriller—icy, intimate, and right in my crime-noir wheelhouse.

path_5.title: Handful of Dust, A (1988)
path_5.feeling: A tart class-skewering melodrama I admired more for its sting than its emotional pull.

path_5.title: Paperhouse (1988)
path_5.feeling: A haunting child’s-eye dreamscape that blends tender ache with uncanny dread—very much my mood.

path_5.title: Big Combo, The (1955)
path_5.feeling: Chiaroscuro menace and obsession distilled—pure noir nourishment.

path_5.title: Ravenous (1999)
path_5.feeling: Savage frontier cannibalism with a blackly comic pulse

path_5.title: Gold Diggers of 1933 (1933)
path_5.feeling: Spry pre‑Code sparkle with backstage grit and numbers that still pop.

path_5.title: Old Boy (2003)
path_5.feeling: Operatic vengeance and moral rot delivered with jolting style—bruising and unforgettable.

path_5.title: Farewell to Arms, A (1932)
path_5.feeling: Glossy, old-school wartime swoon that feels more tidy than tragic to me.

path_5.title: Time After Time (1979)
path_5.feeling: A jaunty high-concept chase with enough sci‑fi spice to keep me grinning.

path_5.title: Gunfight at the O.K. Corral (1957)
path_5.feeling: Solid, stoic oater with mythic swagger, if a shade too square for me.

path_5.title: Snapper, The (1993)
path_5.feeling: Warm, lived-in Irish family chaos with humor and heart that feels genuinely human.

path_5.title: Last Days, The (1998)
path_5.feeling: Talky, reverent history play that intrigues intellectually more than it grips dramatically.

path_5.title: Jackie Brown (1997)
path_5.feeling: Laid-back, soulful caper of aging grifters and second chances—richly characterful and sly.

path_5.title: Hound of the Baskervilles, The (1939)
path_5.feeling: Foggy, Gothic mystery comfort food—handsome, pulpy, and pleasingly eerie.

path_5.title: One Day in September (1999)
path_5.feeling: A taut, upsetting historical account with clear-eyed context that kept me riveted.

path_5.title: Lookout, The (2007)
path_5.feeling: A spare, empathetic crime spiral whose small stakes and bruised souls drew me in.

path_5.title: Conformist, The (Conformista, Il) (1970)
path_5.feeling: Lush, chilling moral rot rendered with formal precision—catnip for my cinephile side.

path_5.title: Four Weddings and a Funeral (1994)
path_5.feeling: Witty, amiable rom‑com that charms more than it lingers for me.

path_5.title: All About My Mother (Todo sobre mi madre) (1999)
path_5.feeling: Generous, messy humanism with stylish flourish—moving without tipping saccharine.

path_5.title: Hoodlum (1997)
path_5.feeling: Handsome period crime pageant that satisfies as pulp even if it rarely cuts deep.

path_5.title: Ms. 45 (a.k.a. Angel of Vengeance) (1981)
path_5.feeling: Grimy, abrasive revenge fever dream with a stark moral chill I respond to.

path_5.title: 35 Up (1991)
path_5.feeling: Decades-deep human portraiture that’s quietly profound—my documentary sweet spot.
